headline: Scattered Problems Reported at the Polls
summary: Election Day was largely free of high-profile voting problems or irregularities, though there were scattered cases of alleged voter intimidation or suppression.

headline: In Ohio, Absentee Ballots Surge
summary: In Ohio's Franklin County, home of the Democratic stronghold of Columbus, the percentage of absentee ballots is expected to be one of the highest in recent memory.

summary: Spain's Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria said it has agreed to buy a 24.9% stake in Turkey's Garanti Bankasi for $5.84 billion.

summary: Important issues that need resolving.

headline: Pride International Evaluates Options
summary: Offshore driller Pride International is evaluating strategic options that could include a possible sale of the Houston-based oil-services company.  contractor.

headline: GOP House Victory to Yield Business-Friendly Policies
summary: Republicans looked set to sweep control of the House of Representatives Tuesday in a victory that promises more business-friendly tax policy and relief to the oil, gas and nuclear industries as well as automakers, airlines and financial services firms.

headline: Westpac Profit Rises 84%
summary: Westpac reported an 84% rise in full year net profit to US$6.3 billion and said it will consider lending rates over coming days.

headline: CFTC Probing Natural-Gas Trades
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is probing a range of natural-gas derivatives-trading activity spanning parts of 2008, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: U.K.'s CapCo Faces Test
summary: The U.K.'s CapCo, spun off from Liberty International this year, has begun to deliver on its pledge to reshape Covent Garden with trendier shops that can boost retail sales and rents.

headline: Old GM Bonds Hit by IPO Expectations
summary: Legacy bonds of General Motors Corp. were hit hard as reported terms of an anticipated initial public offering later this month fell short of bond market expectations.

headline: Cyclist Landis to Stand Trial in France
summary: American cyclist Floyd Landis and his coach will stand trial in a hacking case involving a French doping lab.

headline: Opposition to Alaska Mine Builds Up
summary: Jewelers from the U.K. and France have joined ranks with U.S. jewelers such as Tiffany & Co. to oppose the construction of a large Alaskan gold and copper mine that could harm one of the world's largest wild salmon habitats.

headline: Tokyo Recalls Moscow Envoy
summary: A territorial spat between Japan and Russia intensified Tuesday as Tokyo said it would call home its ambassador to Moscow a day after Russian President Dmitry Medvedev visited a disputed island in the Russian Far East.

headline: Union Drives Pick Up at Small Airlines
summary: Organizing drives at several smaller airlines have picked up momentum now that a federal rule makes it easier for unions to win members at carriers.

headline: Vietnamese Premier Faces Fallout on Vinashin
summary: A Vietnamese lawmaker called for a no-confidence vote against Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung over his handling of a debt crisis at one of Vietnam's biggest state-owned firms.

headline: Illinois Voters Report Polling-Place Problems
summary: Voters in Chicago are reporting confusion among poll workers about when voters must receive a provisional ballot.

headline: Citadel Adjusts Pay
summary: Citadel Broadcasting's board altered compensation plans for directors and top executives amid complaints that the radio broadcaster skirted terms outlined in its recent bankruptcy reorganization plan.

headline: Seahawk Drilling Weighs Sale
summary: The board of Seahawk Drilling said that it's seeking options to boost shareholder returns, including a sale or recapitalization of the company.

headline: Campaign Battles Over 'Coordination' Rage On
summary: In the partisan battle over campaign spending by independent groups, "coordination" has become a fighting word.

headline: A GreenhouseIn Montreal
summary: BTB Real Estate Investment Trust has been seeking to transform an industrial building in Montreal into trendy office space for designers. Last year, two entrepreneurs approached with a way that might help make that happen: They wanted to build a greenhouse on the roof.

headline: ASX Chief Dismisses Critics
summary: The head of Australia's ASX said the company will formally apply this month for approval of its takeover by Singapore Exchange and dismissed the concerns of lawmakers who argue the buyout isn't in the country's national interest.

headline: Ex-NBA Star Files Suit Against Morgan Keegan
summary: Former basketball star Horace Grant filed a $3 million claim against Morgan Keegan, alleging its legal strategy in a case about his mutual-fund losses forced him to cash in an NBA pension.

summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Nov. 3
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Nov. 3

headline: On Sale: Put Protection on Retailers
summary: Buyout hopes have driven up call costs in the retail sector over the past few months, making protective put options comparatively affordable.

headline: Vornado Results Suggest Sector on the Rebound
summary: The REIT's net fell 26%, compared with a year-ago gain, but revenue rose as the company benefited from higher rents and occupancy levels at retail properties.

headline: M&T Happy toUse Its TARP
summary: None

headline: Investors Stock Up on Treasurys
summary: Treasurys maturing in the next five to 30 years rose as investors who believe the Federal Reserve will launch another large scale bond-buying program loaded up on U.S. government notes and bonds.

headline: Feingold Voters Have Obama in Mind
summary: Turnout was strong in a mostly African-American neighborhood on Milwaukee's West Side, where many voters came out to express support for a man not on the ballot: President Barack Obama.

headline: U.S. Stocks Rise
summary: The Dow industrials rose 64.10 points as investors awaited the results of U.S. midterm elections and the week's Fed meeting.

headline: Paying for News Online
summary: News Corp. said its move to place its U.K. newspapers, the Times and the Sunday Times, behind a paywall in July has led to more than 105,000 readers paying for its content online.

headline: Emerson Invests in Emerging Markets
summary: Emerson Electric is stepping up its investments in emerging markets, CEO David Farr said.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Sotheby's Kicks Off Fall Art Auctions
summary: Sotheby's kicks off a major round of fall art auctions on Tuesday when it tries to sell between $195 million and $266 million worth of Impressionist and modern art, up from $181 million at a similar sale last November. Here is a preview.

headline: Oil Rallies Ahead of Fed
summary: Crude-oil futures advanced to their highest settlement since May as the dollar weakened ahead of the expected Wednesday announcement of the size of a Federal Reserve stimulus plan.

headline: SEC to Vote on Proposed 'Naked Access' Ban
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission will vote Nov. 3 on whether to adopt a proposed ban on "naked access," a trading arrangement that allows some firms to trade anonymously.

headline: Danish-Inspired Loft
summary: The owners of this two-story loft in the West Village used one stone slab throughout the entire home and decorated the place with high-end Danish furnishings.

headline: Turkey Blocks, Unblocks YouTube
summary: YouTube was blocked and unblocked again in Turkey on Tuesday, as a dispute continued over the popular video-sharing site's refusal to remove videos deemed illegal by Turkish courts, world-wide..

headline: BBVA's Well-Judged Turkish Adventure
summary: Shareholders needn't fret about BBVA's $6 billion acquisition of a 24.9% stake in Turkey's biggest bank. It gives the Spanish banking giant a leading position in Europe's most dynamic emerging market.

headline: Photos of the Day: Nov. 2
summary: In Tuesday's pictures, police confront protesters in southern Italy, a gas explosion destroys homes in Manchester, England, and Mount Merapi spews more ash in Indonesia.

headline: Russia Backs a Renault-Nissan Stake in AvtoVAZ
summary: Russia on Tuesday gave its backing to French car maker Renault SA and its Japanese alliance partner Nissan Motor Co. building up a 50% stake in car maker OAO AvtoVAZ.

headline: Wisconsin Advances Rail Plan
summary: Wisconsin agreed to spend the full $810 million in federal money granted for a high-speed passenger-rail line between Milwaukee and Madison.

headline: Harrisburg Doesn't Have Cash for Debt Payments
summary: Harrisburg, the cash-strapped capital of Pennsylvania, doesn't have enough money to make two debt payments totaling $305,952 on Nov. 15.

headline: USDA Unveils Controversial Crop Plan
summary: The USDA unveiled controversial plans to again approve genetically modified sugar beets in time for planting next year, a move that would nullify a federal court ruling in August.

headline: BP's Enduring Taste for Exploration
summary: For BP, throwing money at exploration is probably a smart strategy, but it calls for investors to be patient.

headline: U.K. Postal Service Sees Profits Shrink
summary: The U.K.'s state-owned postal service Royal Mail Group reported a sharp fall in operating profit, giving ammunition to the U.K. government, which wants to privatize most of the service.

headline: CFTC, EU Vow Cooperation on Swaps Oversight
summary: The European Commission recently unveiled part of its plan for regulating over-the-counter derivatives, while the CFTC is working to implement the derivatives provisions of the Dodd-Frank law.

headline: Solid Earnings Drive Stock Gains in Europe
summary: European stocks rose on Tuesday, helped by well-received earnings from blue chips and strong regional manufacturing data. Asian markets ended broadly higher.

headline: Hungary's Proposed Budget Raises Questions
summary: Hungary's newly released draft budget for next year is failing to ease concerns about fiscal sustainability despite broad agreement that the proposed spending plan will allow the country to meet the EU's deficit target for the first time.

headline: Rusal Not Interested in Selling Norilsk Stake
summary: Russian aluminum giant United Co. Rusal PLC has no interest in selling its stake in polar miner OAO Norilsk Nickel and reiterated that the company is undervalued at its current market price, according to a letter seen by Dow Jones Newswires on Tuesday.

headline: U.K., France Sign Defense Pacts
summary: The U.K. prime minister said Britain and France are "natural" defense partners, as the two governments signed treaties aimed at deepening nuclear ties.

headline: Energy Plays Lead European Stocks
summary: European stocks ended higher Tuesday, helped by well-received earnings from leading blue-chips and strong euro-zone manufacturing data out of the region.

headline: UniCredit Boss Faces Showdown
summary: UniCredit Chairman Dieter Rampl faces a showdown with the bank's governance committee in a dispute over strategy that could lead him to resign by April.

headline: How the Series Was Won
summary: The San Francisco Giants beat the Texas Rangers in five games to earn the title of 2010 world champions. Here's a look at some of the best photography from the series.

headline: BOE Weighs Conflicting Messages
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep policy on hold at its meeting, but it will have to weigh conflicting factors about the period ahead for the U.K. economy.

headline: Developing Markets Buoy Reckitt Benckiser
summary: Reckitt Benckiser posted a 19% rise in third-quarter net profit as demand for its personal-care products in developing markets offset weakness in Europe and North America.

headline: China Worried About Inflation
summary: The People's Bank of China, fresh from its first interest-rate increase in nearly three years, said it remains concerned about inflationary risks.

headline: Refinancing If You're Over 50
summary: SmartMoney: Rates are low, but anyone over 50 should think twice before refinancing a mortgage. Here's why.

headline: Och-Ziff Distributable Earnings Rise
summary: Hedge-fund manager Och-Ziff Capital Management reported a 52% increase in distributable third-quarter earnings, which don't include charges related to its initial public offering.

headline: The Great Tech-doors
summary: With the latest well-designed outdoor gear, even the most urban of urbanites can comfortably discover the wonders of the woods

headline: Ireland Adds to Euro Zone Woes
summary: Ireland's borrowing costs soar amid fears its burgeoning bank rescue effort could lead to a Greek-style fiscal crisis. A rare bright spot for the country's economy: a modest expansion in manufacturing.

headline: China Construction Bank to Raise $9.2 Billion
summary: China Construction Bank said it plans to raise $9.2 billion in a rights issue in Shanghai and Hong Kong, less than it originally planned to raise.

headline: LNG Business Lifts BG Group's Profit
summary: BG Group posted a 7% rise in third-quarter net profit due to a strong performance in its liquefied natural-gas business.

headline: Imperial Tobacco Profit Jumps
summary: Imperial Tobacco more than doubled its full-year net profit due to higher sales, but cigarette volumes fell and the company said it continues to focus on cost-cutting.

headline: Will Your 401(k) Plan Survive?
summary: Recent market turmoil and regulatory changes are driving both employers and workers to reassess their retirement plans.

headline: ADM Profit Drops 30%
summary: Archer Daniels Midland's fiscal first-quarter profit slid 30% on the negative impact of changing inventory valuations, which masked stronger volumes and stronger-than-expected revenue growth.

headline: MasterCard Earnings Top Forecasts
summary: MasterCard's third-quarter profit grew 15%, topping Wall Street's expectations, as consumers and businesses spent more amid an improving global economy.

headline: Metro's Net Profit Doubles
summary: Germany's Metro raised its full-year forecast and said third-quarter net profit more than doubled on cost cutting and stronger sales.

headline: Parcel Bombs Explode in Greece
summary: Small parcel bombs exploded at the Swiss and Russian embassies in Athens on Tuesday and suspicious packages were detonated by police outside parliament, the Bulgarian embassy and a courier company. (More: Parcel Bombs Explode in Greece)

headline: NYSE Euronext Profit Up Despite Revenue Drop
summary: Exchange operator NYSE Euronext said third-quarter net profit rose 2.3% from a year earlier, as growth in its trading technology arm and a deferred tax benefit countered pressure on revenue from weak trading volume.

headline: China's Xueda Leaps in Trading Debut
summary: Tutoring-services company Xueda Education opened at $14.30 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up nearly 51% from its IPO price of $9.50.

headline: SEC to Settle With Madoff Figures
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission has agreed to settle civil charges against associates of convicted Ponzi-scheme operator Bernard Madoff.

headline: Medco's Net Rises 11%
summary: Medco's third-quarter profit rose 11% and adjusted results beat analysts' expectations as revenue advanced on business from new clients and higher brand-name drug prices.

headline: Asian Markets Rise, Await Fed
summary: Asian markets ended slightly higher in light trade as investors awaited U.S. central bank meetings this week. The Australian dollar touched U.S. dollar parity, and Korea's Kospi rose 0.2%.

headline: Generic Drug Sales Boost Teva
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries reported strong profit and revenue growth, driven by sales of flagship multiple-sclerosis drug Copaxone and its generic operations, especially in North America.

headline: Yonkers Stone House Restoration

headline: Harley to Make Motorcycles in India

headline: How to Sell a Small Business
summary: Passing the business along to the next generation might not be part of your plan. Instead, it may be time to take what you've built with blood, sweat and tears—and cash out.

headline: World Bank Cuts Russia Growth Forecast
summary: The World Bank cut its forecasts for Russian economic growth in 2010 and said that imports would continue rising, a factor that may continue to pressure the already weak ruble.

summary: While major networks offer flashy election coverage, local webcasts of polling stations and other vote-related activity are less splashy but still have their followers.

headline: Tenet Margins Narrow
summary: Tenet Healthcare reported disappointing results, even though it returned to the black. Revenue was flat and profit margins narrowed.

headline: Packer, Murdoch at Odds With Ten
summary: James Packer and News Corp.'s Lachlan Murdoch were at loggerheads with Australian broadcaster Ten over their desire to replace the chairman and win a third seat on the board.

headline: Irish Default Insurance Cost Hits Record
summary: The cost of insuring Irish government debt against the risk of default hit a record as investors continued to fret about the cost of bailing out the country's banks.

headline: Australian Dollar Soars on Rate Decision

headline: Japanese Yields Ease; Strong 10-Year Auction
summary: Japanese government bond yields generally eased on a stronger-than-expected 10-year debt sale.

headline: Lee Now a Free Agent in High Demand
summary: Following the World Series, many teams will be coming after Cliff Lee, a pitcher who at 32 has won a Cy Young Award, could command close to $30 million in annual salary and had been the surest thing in this postseason until the Giants beat him twice.

headline: RBI Raises Interest Rates
summary: India's central bank raised interest rates for a sixth time this year, as expected, but said it sees little need for more hikes near term as its tighter monetary policy acts to bring down inflation that has plagued Asia's third biggest economy.

headline: Euro-Zone Output Growth Picks Up
summary: A final survey by Markit showed that output growth in the euro zone's manufacturing sector picked for the first time in three months in October.

headline: Fore! Sponsorship money heads for Asia
summary: The chatter ahead of the HSBC Shanghai Champions golf tournament is whether Lee Westwood or Tiger Woods will emerge as the world's No.1 golf player. Either way—the winner's share of $7 million in prize money is from a deep pool of  sponsorship funds in Asia.

headline: Mitsui Profit More Than Doubles
summary: Mitsui & Co. said net profit more than doubled in the latest quarter, but it has yet to book any liabilities related to charges from BP related to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Russia, Japan Row Grows Over Islands
summary: Russian President Dmitry Medvedev visited an island that has long the subject of a dispute with Japan, a move that could cause a major headache for a government already stung by a bitter territorial spat with China.

headline: U.K. Job Losses Pegged at 1.6 Million
summary: The U.K. private sector will need to create about 1.6 million jobs over the next five years to keep the economy running at the current pace, according to a new survey.

headline: The Elephant In Sands China's Casino
summary: This has been a great year for shareholders of Sands China, operator of casinos in Macau and Singapore. But expansion plans have stalled. Could their luck be running out?

headline: Okinawa Vote Threatens U.S. Plans
summary: The twists and turns of a key local election in Japan have put a considerable barrier in front of efforts by Tokyo and Washington to strengthen their security ties.

headline: Apple Takes 95% of Tablet Market
summary: Apple dominated the global market for tablets in the third quarter amid limited competition for its iPad, a situation that is likely to change as more devices come to market.

headline: Tribal Ties Dash War On Terror in Yemen
summary: As Yemen deploys more troops against the al Qaeda affiliate suspected in the foiled package-bomb plot, tribal feuds sparked by the government offensive create a new hurdle.

headline: Giants Pitcher in Rarefied October Air
summary: The Giants' Madison Bumgarner is the youngest rookie pitcher to pitch at least six scoreless innings in a World Series. And the NBA names its Mr. Average.

headline: Doubts Cloud Gold's Bright Future
summary: The outlook for gold prices is tarnished by the erosion of several longstanding factors that have proven supportive for the yellow metal in the past.

headline: Google Reposts Barred Turkish Videos
summary: Google appeared to be set for a renewed clash with Turkey's government, when it reposted videos that a court had ruled insulting to the republic's founder.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Nov. 2, 2010.

headline: OPEC Talks and Oil Prices Jump
summary: The Saudi oil minister suggested that the oil market could tolerate prices as high as $90 a barrel, increasing his previous estimate and signaling to the market that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would let the price drift higher.

headline: Pakistan Should Move On, as India Has
summary: Regarding Ryan Crocker's "Pakistan Is Not America's Enemy" (op-ed, Oct 12): Pakistan's India-centric policy is foolish. India has moved on to bigger and better things, while the "Land of the Pure" wallows in self-destructive behavior.

headline: Ex-Foes Back Landlord's New Deal
summary: Controversial landlord Laurence Gluck re-emerges with a deal for Tivoli Towers in Crown Heights, Brooklyn—but this time former foes are backing the deal.

headline: We Are Keeping Our Eyes on the Prize at the NAACP
summary: Jason Riley's view of the NAACP—our history, priorities and future—is misguided. ("The NAACP's Unhealthy Obsession with the Tea Party," op-ed, Oct. 25).

headline: Nissan-China Venture Ups Sales Goal
summary: Nissan's China joint venture with Dongfeng increased its annual sales goal to 1.5 million vehicles in that country from one million by 2012, after reaching the one-million mark two years early

headline: Stone House and View That Rocks
summary: Lost after a house-hunting expedition in the New York suburbs, Maria Gouras and her husband stumbled upon a dilapidated stone-walled estate in Yonkers. Restoring the home overlooking the Hudson River wasn't easy.

headline: Old Standbys Voted Off Coney Island
summary: Shoot the Freak is out and Nathan's Famous hot dogs is in as the ongoing revitalization of Coney Island continues to transform the boardwalk.

headline: Private Equity Steps on the Gas
summary: The stock market is down on natural gas. But private-equity buyers can take a longer-term view, especially when valuations are this low and debt is this cheap.

headline: Barun S. Mitra: In Bush's Footsteps in India
summary: President Obama's lack of political vision will make his trip a damp squib.

headline: For Utilities, Hot Summer, Hotter Profits
summary: Electric utilities posted strong third-quarter results thanks to increased demand from a hotter-than-usual summer. Long-range forecasts calling for a colder-than-normal winter across the nation's northern states could fire up profits this quarter, too.

headline: The Harmony Prize
summary: The army chief who supervised the Tiananmen Massacre receives an award for promoting global good will.

headline: GM's New Sticker Price: $50 Billion
summary: The U.S. will cut its ownership stake in GM below the symbolically important 50% when the car maker relists its stock, but it will be tough for the U.S. to break even on its investment.

headline: McKesson to Buy US Oncology
summary: McKesson said it will buy privately held oncology-services company US Oncology in a deal valued at about $2.16 billion, including debt.

headline: Clubs, Eateries Target Local Boards
summary: A group of high-profile restaurateurs are trying to form a trade association. One of their main gripes: Community boards are unfair.

headline: Ryanair Lifts Full-Year Forecast
summary: Ryanair raised its full-year net profit forecast after reporting a 32% increase in second-quarter net profit as higher yields and increased capacity offset higher fuel costs.

headline: Cnooc, Ghana Petroleum Rebuffed
summary: China's Cnooc and state-owned Ghana National Petroleum made a failed joint $5 billion bid to buy Kosmos Energy's assets in the African nation.

headline: Canada's Mills Lumber Back to Life
summary: Timber giants, squeezed by the U.S. housing slump and global recession, are starting to stir again in Canada's north woods thanks to insatiable demand from China.

headline: McGurn: From the South Bronx to West Point
summary: A public school discovers the Army.

headline: Moogfest's Difficult Dilemma
summary: A festival that used to be a low-wattage, one-day affair celebrating the legacy of Robert Moog, inventor and electronic-music pioneer, may have outgrown its original mission. That's not all bad.

headline: Guilty Plea in Ponzi That Sacked Elway
summary: The hedge-fund manager facing charges related to a Ponzi scheme that conned some of Denver's wealthiest people, including former Broncos quarterback John Elway, pleaded guilty.

headline: Air Passenger Screening Draws Scrutiny
summary: This week's renewed global concern over how to ferret out dangerous air cargo comes as rhetoric also grows heated over another major area of airline safety, passenger screening.

headline: Low Rates Trump Week's Events
summary: Northrop Grumman, Northern Trust and New York Times Co. were each selling bonds, shrugging off potential risks of U.S. elections Tuesday, the Fed's meeting Wednesday and Friday's closely watched jobs report.

headline: Flight Studied as Possible Test Run
summary: U.S. authorities in September intercepted packages containing papers, books and other harmless household items shipped from Yemen to Chicago in what officials believe may have been a test run for an attack by al Qaeda.

headline: Study: Common Hormone Worsens Pain
summary: In The Research Report, Jeremy Singer-Vine summarizes new medical findings on cortisone, anorexia, border bias, hospital infections, blindness and touch, testosterone and typographical errors.

headline: U.K., France Move Closer on Defense
summary: The U.K. and France will sign defense treaties, bringing greater cooperation between Europe's two biggest military powers in areas ranging from nuclear testing to the potential deployment of a joint expeditionary force.

headline: Sales Boost on the Verizon for iPhone
summary: Consumers who believe iPhone is coming to Verizon Wireless will likely wait before upgrading their phones. Investors, however, should act now and buy Apple stock.

headline: In the Stadium Lot, Another Contest
summary: The Bing National Tailgating Championship will consist of six regional challenges in Houston where entrants will be judged on cooking, tailgate spirit, parking lot agility and sports knowledge.

headline: Vehicle Sales Tumble in Japan
summary: Japan's auto sales marked their biggest on-year drop in 18 month after the expiry of government buying incentives, in another headache for the industry as it struggles to cope with the impact of the stronger yen.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Con Coughlin: The Terrorists That Got Away
summary: If it weren't for Western naivete, the Yemen-based group that hatched last week's failed bomb plot might never have developed in the first place.

headline: Reagan's Rebound Offers Lesson for Democrats
summary: Some Democrats think that political recovery requires an intense focus on economic growth, a strategy that paid off for Reagan after Republicans took a midterm hit in 1982, writes Gerald Seib.

headline: China's Humiliation Is No Mere Put-On
summary: The destruction of Beijing's Old Summer Palace at the hands of British and French troops is part of China's national psyche.

headline: DeLay Corruption Trial Starts
summary: Opening statements began for the trial of former House Majority Leader DeLay, who is accused of helping to illegally finance Texas legislative races in 2002.

headline: Dutch Cyclists Resist Helmets
summary: Among Holland's millions of bikers, helmets are almost nonexistent. Now a number of doctors, safety advocates and bike-gear producers are trying to get through Dutch skulls that headgear would protect them.

headline: Simon Looks for Growth
summary: Simon Property's earnings more than doubled amid higher rental and occupancy rates but growth through acquisitions poses a bigger challenge.

headline: Rolling Dice on Giant Casino Complex
summary: The massive City Center casino complex opened in Las Vegas last December amid the steepest decline in tourism there in decades. Now, its owners are still scrambling to figure out how to fix the 67-acre development's financial problems.
